instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message:
Hello,
i am working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no green light. It was water damaged an i fixed some corrosion already. Now, if i plug the charger in it shows a green light for a second but than it turns off again. Without unplugging the charger the light comes back on after a minute or so and than turns off again instantly. (actually one or two times i want to measure it it stays on and the cpu was getting warm) I measured around and saw that <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is not there and also <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> (and so also <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL>) is not there (causing The <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> to stop working and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> to be missing). I checked for a short to GND on <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> but there is no. <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is something between 1,2V and 0,6V (slowls fading) until it peaks to 16V (when the green light appears for a second) and than fades away again. I already replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> twice (to be sure because the probepoint of <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> next to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> was corroded and not conducting anymore but the actual Pad (Pad 2) of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and the rest of the line looks fine so far- i fixed that probepoint). I also had to run a wire under (to pin 3) <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> because there was another a no longer conducting Probepoint. Now my wire (at pin 3) is conducting connected to the metal case of <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> (i measured some voltages there and discovered this connecction) but as far as i understand: this in clearly not ideal and i´ll correct that if it works but for now it should not be the problem, as the case of <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> is only soldered to NC Pads on the board. I also followed <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> to F6905 and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is also only 1,2V-0,6V. Now i don´t know hat to do. I tryed a different DCIN board already and i will try another tomorow to make sure it is fine.
Thanks for any help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: I tryed a different DCIN board and still the same. But i just let it sit there plugged in and it seems as it will turn on every time if i just wait long enough. Than i can also see an apple (with no backlight - ill adress that when it works) on the screen and a normal picture on an external monitor. But it needs really long to turn the green light on. Can this be caused by the keyboard/Trackpad connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, should be 20 ohm, check voltage on bothe pins should be about 16V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: Both pins have 0,6V slowly going down when the light is off. Resistance is 23OHM. But after a minute or so it starts, chimes and the voltage is back up to 16V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: There should always be voltage on <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>. Measure voltage on pins of <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: I measured <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> and it has 0,X V at all three pins slowly doing down. I followed <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> back to F6905 anf there is also the same low voltage. But as it starts the voltage goes back up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: I noticed <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> getting  hot and replaced it. I also corrected my jumper so that it is no longer connected to the case of <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> (i measured all connections of <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and they conduct only to where they should  (i also checked them the first time... maybe the <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> i took from a donor was slowly dying...)) and now it turns on every time. But <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> is still getting hot. On this machines the whole board is pretty hot so i guess that is normal for this model. I repaired the backlight and after that i noticed that it won´t boot up all the way. If i try to install an OS but it hangs after the apple disappears and it i want to boot from a drive with an OS installed.  It also stops with a white screen after the apple finished loading. I tryed differend HDDs and HDD cables but still the same. Even without the HDD cable connected it won´t get to the installation menu. Now i am stuck again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> is getting hot because it is not being told to turn on. Check the trace to the gate <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> and trace to the ISL.

It probably hangs during boot because the GPU is also fucked.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: I replaced <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> and it seems to be cooler now. (but still nearly the whole board is warm/hot. I´m pretty sure i replaced or at least measured <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> before because the trace to the gate was burned. The trace to the ISL is fine and the trace under <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> (pin 3) is my jumper and should be fine as far as i can measure. Is there a way to start it using just the integrated Intel GPU for testing? Is this the model where <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> fails often?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: Why don't you just measure the gate voltage? Heat up GPU to see if it boots again. No <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> is on 2010 boards, not on 2915.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: Voltage to the Gate (PIN 1 of <RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR>) is 6,35V when turned on. Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR> is 16V so i assume thats fine as <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> is a PMOS. I heated the GPU with my hot air until i couldnt touch it anymore but still the same. Should i heat it more? Also there is no visible issue on the picture. It just stays with a white screen after the apple finished loading

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: Hanging on a grey screen is 90% a GPU or VRAM issue. Heat up to 100C so a wet finger on the GPU sizzles. Also check for damaged components around GPU/VRAM. Is the original edge bonding glue still present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message:
No Title

The edge bonding is still there. The only corrosion around the GPU was around <CHIP>ISL6263</CHIP>. There was one trace burned - i run a wire there. I attached a picture too. Should i replace the chip as well to be sure its good? I could not get it so boot up but i´ll try heating it more slowly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: So that means there was corrosion in GPU are. Could be corrosion under VRAM/GPU or corroded trace/resistor still in that area. It may be a good idea to replace that ISL and inspect all traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: I replaced the ISL and the first time the fans won´t spin anymore. I replaced it again and now its back to the grey screen. After that i heated the GPU again very much and (unfortunately) it decided to work again. So you were right again. Failing GPU... Thank you for the help. I learned a lot anyways

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: In reality every 2914/2915 board you will get that has not had the GPU replaced will need it. I cannot warranty these boards for any repair without putting a new GPU on it. So basically any liquid damaged 2914/15 are a write off if you want to provide a warranty on it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: Ok, so better don´t touch these or tell the owner that there is no warramty... Thank you for the lesson. Are there actually any reliable good GPUs on the market or still only reballed crap?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light?
threads.message: GPUs are pretty much no where to be found. The ones you do find are 99% fake reballed garbage with 2016/2017 date codes put on them.
